node.title: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? Itâ€™s Complicated.
node.alt: A Covid-19 patient in the intensive care unit of a hospital in La Mesa, Calif.
node.description: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
node.content: ["It\u2019s one of the most well-known takeaways of the pandemic: Men die of Covid-19 more often than women do.", "Early on, some scientists suspected the reason was primarily biological, and that sex-based treatments for men \u2014 like estrogen injections or androgen blockers \u2014 could help reduce their risk of dying.", "But a new study analyzing sex differences in Covid-19 deaths over time in the United States suggests that the picture is much more complicated.", "While men overall died at a higher rate than women, the trends varied widely over time and by state, the study found. That suggests that social factors \u2014 like job types, behavioral patterns and underlying health issues \u2014 played a big role in the apparent sex differences, researchers said.", "\u201cThere is no single story to tell about sex disparities during this pandemic, even within the United States,\u201d said Sarah Richardson, director of the GenderSci Lab at Harvard University, which studies how biological sex interacts with cultural influences in society.", "Dr. Richardson\u2019s team began collecting sex data on Covid cases and deaths early in the pandemic, before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began collecting and sharing this information. Her research group logged on every Monday morning and checked each state\u2019s data, maintaining it on a tracker on the lab\u2019s website. The tracker, which stretches from April 2020 through December 2021, is the only source of sex-based weekly Covid-19 data by state.", "That data enabled the researchers to analyze Covid case rates and deaths across all 50 states and Washington, D.C. over a period of 55 weeks.", "Nationally, they found no significant differences in case rates between men and women. But the death rates \u2014 the number of deaths among men or women divided by the state\u2019s total population of each sex \u2014 were often higher among men than women.", "Just how much higher depended on the state and the date. In Texas, for example, men died at a notably higher rate in every week the research group analyzed. In New York, men died at a higher rate than women \u2014 although the gap was not quite as large as in Texas \u2014 during all but three weeks. But in Connecticut, women died more than men in 22 of the weeks analyzed.", "\u201cYou can have states right next door to each other, like Connecticut and New York, that have a totally different pattern but yet experienced the same wave,\u201d Dr. Richardson said.", "Cumulatively over 55 weeks, mortality rates were slightly higher for women in two states, Rhode Island and Massachusetts. In nine states, including Connecticut, the rates were roughly equal. And in the rest of the country, death rates were higher for men.", "Sex differences in genes, hormones or immune responses are not likely to explain these differences, the researchers said.", "\u201cThere would be no reason for biology to be that variable across time and space,\u201d said Katharine Lee, a biological anthropologist and engineer at Washington University in St. Louis and an author of the new study.", "But social and behavioral factors, the researchers said, could help explain many of these patterns.", "For example, men are more likely to have jobs in transportation, factories, meatpacking plants, agriculture and construction \u2014 occupations with higher rates of Covid-19 exposure and fatalities. Men are also more likely to be incarcerated and to experience homelessness, increasing their risk of virus exposure.", "Women are more likely than men to report hand washing, mask wearing and complying with social distancing restrictions, all of which may lower their risk of contracting the virus. And women are more likely to be vaccinated.", "The researchers speculated that states with more public health restrictions might see reduced sex differences. In New York, which saw a significantly higher number of male deaths in the first six weeks of the pandemic, mortality rates evened out once restrictions were put in place. The observed differences in New York could also be partly explained by better data collection, as well as underreporting of deaths in long-term care facilities, where the majority of residents are women.", "Dr. Richardson\u2019s research group did not have access to age data for each sex, an important factor since older people are more likely to die of Covid and different states have different age distributions. Even before Covid, men had a lower life expectancy, possibly driven by higher rates of certain chronic conditions, more risk-taking behaviors and more dangerous jobs. That \u201cpre-existing mortality gap,\u201d rather than a specific male vulnerability to the virus, could help explain the disparity with Covid, Richardson said.", "Still, independent experts said the new findings should not lead researchers to entirely discount the role of biology.", "\u201cYou can\u2019t attribute observations about things like mortality from a complex disease like Covid and say it\u2019s all biology,\u201d said Sabra Klein, a microbiologist and co-director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Women\u2019s Health, Sex and Gender Research. \u201cBut I also don\u2019t think you can say it\u2019s all social and it\u2019s all behavioral, either.\u201d", "Using electronic health records from Johns Hopkins hospitals in Maryland and Washington D.C., Dr. Klein found that there were higher rates of severe Covid illness and death among men. But biostatistical modeling showed that this disparity could be substantially accounted for by greater inflammatory responses among men, suggesting a biological difference.", "And in experiments looking at the effects of Covid in hamsters by sex, which can be useful since they don\u2019t include the social factors present in humans, Dr. Klein\u2019s group showed that males fared worse. Other studies have also shown that women produce a stronger immune response than men.", "Other experts said that having access to more granular data \u2014 on factors like race, income and education level \u2014 would enable the researchers to take a more nuanced look at the observed variations in sex differences.", "\u201cI think they\u2019re doing a lot with a little,\u201d said Derek Griffith, a public health psychologist and co-director of the Racial Justice Institute at Georgetown University.", "\u201cThe data sources that document these differences don\u2019t usually have the capacity to help explain them,\u201d he said, pointing to the health impacts of stress, financial burdens and discrimination that might underlie racial or gender differences in health outcomes but are difficult to quantify.", "Dr. Griffith said that racial differences in Covid outcomes were similarly complex. In the earliest stages of the pandemic, scientists speculated that Black people had a lower risk of contracting the virus and possibly had some biological protections, Dr. Griffith said. But when the data started to show that Black people in the U.S. had a higher risk of dying of Covid-19 than white people, the pendulum swung the other way, with some scientists speculating about innate genetic differences.", "Now, Dr. Griffith said, there\u2019s greater recognition of the many socioeconomic factors that influence health disparities. \u201cAnd yet in both cases, with sex and with race, the knee-jerk assumption is that it must be biological,\u201d he said.", "Dr. Richardson\u2019s Harvard group is hopeful that other researchers will use its data set to analyze the impacts of states\u2019 varying public health policies.", "But other data gaps remain: Studies have shown that long Covid, for example, disproportionately affects women, yet the disease isn\u2019t tracked consistently at the state level. And the researchers didn\u2019t have data on transgender or gender-nonconforming Covid patients.", "\u201cThese are not as rich of data as we would like to have to characterize the full gendered impact of the Covid pandemic,\u201d Dr. Richardson said."]
